subject: Ensure that pip/setuptools/wheel python wheels are built
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-17 11:11:57.000000000', 'files': ['inventory/group_vars/utility_all.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/bd69ca0b8a197c3986e1fdcfcc12f6e552ad66d2', 'message': 'Ensure that pip/setuptools/wheel python wheels are built

All virtualenvs make use of pip/setuptools/wheel, but none of
them specify that these wheels need to be built and therefore
every venv build process reaches out to pypi to fetch them.

To ensure that the repo container has these built as wheels,
we set the utility container to build them so that these
packages will be available for other venvs to use.

Change-Id: I60f851e1ffa401c92221de14651502306e9b0581
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure that pip/setuptools/wheel python wheels are built

All virtualenvs make use of pip/setuptools/wheel, but none of
them specify that these wheels need to be built and therefore
every venv build process reaches out to pypi to fetch them.

To ensure that the repo container has these built as wheels,
we set the utility container to build them so that these
packages will be available for other venvs to use.

Change-Id: I60f851e1ffa401c92221de14651502306e9b0581
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/01/653401/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Check master/backup router status in DVR functional tests

When two routers are created at the same time, we can't assume the
status of each one. Instead of this, the status of each router is
first checked and then compared to the other router status.

Change-Id: If20a3a414986ea29fbfd50616761c14e5b249b2c
Closes-Bug: #1819160
(cherry picked from commit 8f35331c918f83381951fc4367f43b2805d556ef)

commit_message:
Support Ceph Nautilus release in puppet-ceph

This patch introduces the changes required by osd configuration tasks to
support Nautilus release:

- ceph-disk has been removed and replaced by ceph-volume
- OSDs can not be based on directories anymore, only disks or vg/lv
paths.
- udev configuration is not needed since some releases back.

To pass CI, this job requires to merge [1] and viceversa. To solve
chicken-and-egg, I'm setting p-o-i jobs as non-voting in this patch.
I'll make them voting again after merging both [1] and this one.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/650281/

Change-Id: I15f061dd38ca6729a454ec96c8c8f5ea28c6f0c6
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/puppet-ceph refs/changes/63/650263/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Mandatory. The path for a disk or vg/lv used for the OSD if $fsid { $fsid_option = "--cluster-fsid ${fsid}"exit 1if [ -z $(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} |grep 'cluster fsid' | awk -F'fsid' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') ]; then exit 0 fi test ${fsid} = $(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} |grep 'cluster fsid' | awk -F'fsid' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') if [ $(echo ${data}|cut -c 1) = '/' ]; then disk=${data} else # If data is vg/lv, block device is /dev/vg/lv disk=/dev/${data}if ! test -b \$disk ; then # Since nautilus, only block devices or lvm logical volumes can be used for OSDs exit 1 fi ceph-volume lvm prepare ${osd_type} ${cluster_option}${dmcrypt_options} ${fsid_option} --data ${data} ${journal_opts}ceph-volume lvm list ${data}if [ $(echo ${data}|cut -c 1) = '/' ]; then disk=${data} else # If data is vg/lv, block device is /dev/vg/lv disk=/dev/${data} fi # Since nautilus, only block devices or lvm logical volumes can be used for OSDs exit 1id=$(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} | grep 'osd id'|awk -F 'osd id' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') fsid=$(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} | grep 'osd fsid'|awk -F 'osd fsid' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') ceph-volume lvm activate \$id \$fsidid=$(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} | grep 'osd id'|awk -F 'osd id' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') ps -fCceph-osd|grep \"\--id \$id \"id=$(ceph-volume lvm list ${data} | grep 'osd id'|awk -F 'osd id' '{print \$2}'|tr -d ' ') ceph ${cluster_option} osd out osd.\$idset -x ceph-volume lvm list ${data} if [ \$? -eq 0 ]; then exit 1 exit 0
deleted_lines: # Mandatory. A path in which the OSD data is to be stored. $ceph_check_udev = "ceph-osd-check-udev-${name}" Package<| tag == 'ceph' |> -> Exec[$ceph_check_udev] $udev_rules_file = '/usr/lib/udev/rules.d/95-ceph-osd.rules' exec { $ceph_check_udev: command => "/bin/true # comment to satisfy puppet syntax requirements # Before Infernalis the udev rules race causing the activation to fail so we # disable them. More at: http://www.spinics.net/lists/ceph-devel/msg28436.html mv -f ${udev_rules_file} ${udev_rules_file}.disabled && udevadm control --reload || true ", onlyif => "/bin/true # comment to satisfy puppet syntax requirements set -ex DISABLE_UDEV=$(ceph --version | awk 'match(\$3, /[0-9]+\\.[0-9]+/) {if (substr(\$3, RSTART, RLENGTH) <= 0.94) {print 1} else { print 0 } }') test -f ${udev_rules_file} && test \$DISABLE_UDEV -eq 1 ", logoutput => true, } if $fsid { $fsid_option = "--cluster-uuid ${fsid}" Exec[$ceph_check_udev] -> Exec[$ceph_check_fsid_mismatch]test ${fsid} = $(ceph-disk list $(readlink -f ${data}) | egrep -o '[0-9a-f]{8}-([0-9a-f]{4}-){3}[0-9a-f]{12}')test -z $(ceph-disk list $(readlink -f ${data}) | egrep -o '[0-9a-f]{8}-([0-9a-f]{4}-){3}[0-9a-f]{12}') Exec[$ceph_check_udev] -> Exec[$ceph_prepare] # ceph-disk: prepare should be idempotent http://tracker.ceph.com/issues/7475disk=$(readlink -f ${data}) if ! test -b \$disk ; then echo \$disk | egrep -e '^/dev' -q -v mkdir -p \$disk if getent passwd ceph >/dev/null 2>&1; then chown -h ceph:ceph \$disk ficeph-disk prepare ${osd_type} ${cluster_option}${dmcrypt_options} ${fsid_option} $(readlink -f ${data}) ${journal_opts} udevadm settledisk=$(readlink -f ${data}) ceph-disk list | egrep \" *((\${disk}1?|\${disk}p1?) .*ceph data, (prepared|active)|\\ (\${disk}5?|\${disk}p5?) .*ceph lockbox, (prepared|active), for (\${disk}1?|\${disk}p1?))\" || { test -f \$disk/fsid && test -f \$disk/ceph_fsid && test -f \$disk/magic ;}disk=$(readlink -f ${data}) echo \$disk | egrep -e '^/dev' -q -v mkdir -p \$disk if getent passwd ceph >/dev/null 2>&1; then chown -h ceph:ceph \$disk fi# activate happens via udev when using the entire device if ! test -b \$disk && ! ( test -b \${disk}1 || test -b \${disk}p1 ); then ceph-disk activate \$disk || true fi if test -f ${udev_rules_file}.disabled && ( test -b \${disk}1 || test -b \${disk}p1 ); then ceph-disk activate \${disk}1 || true ficeph-disk list | egrep \" *((\${disk}1?|\${disk}p1?) .*ceph data, active|\\ (\${disk}5?|\${disk}p5?) .*ceph lockbox, active, for (\${disk}1?|\${disk}p1?))\" || ls -ld /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-* | grep \" $(readlink -f ${data})\$\"disk=$(readlink -f ${data}) if [ -z \"\$id\" ] ; then id=$(ceph-disk list | sed -nEe \"s:^ *\${disk}1? .*(ceph data|mounted on).*osd\\.([0-9]+).*:\\2:p\") fi if [ -z \"\$id\" ] ; then id=$(ls -ld /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-* | sed -nEe \"s:.*/${cluster_name}-([0-9]+) *-> *\${disk}\$:\\1:p\" || true) fiset -ex disk=$(readlink -f ${data}) if [ -z \"\$id\" ] ; then id=$(ceph-disk list | sed -nEe \"s:^ *\${disk}1? .*(ceph data|mounted on).*osd\\.([0-9]+).*:\\2:p\") fi if [ -z \"\$id\" ] ; then id=$(ls -ld /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-* | sed -nEe \"s:.*/${cluster_name}-([0-9]+) *-> *\${disk}\$:\\1:p\" || true) fi if [ \"\$id\" ] ; then test ! -d /var/lib/ceph/osd/${cluster_name}-\$id true # if there is no id we do nothing

automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on

Update master for stable/stein

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/stein.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/stein.

commit_message:
docker-rm: check if rpm dependency is actually installed

If the deployment wasn't deployed under Docker, python2-docker package
is missing. Therefore, during the upgrade we don't want to try to remove
the containers under Docker, since they don't exist anyway.

python2-docker is needed by Ansible to remove the containers, so let's
make sure the package is installed, which is the case when the
deployment was under Docker.
If the rpm doesn't exist, we'll skip the tasks and don't try to remove
the containers.

The main case where docker-rm is useful is when upgrading on centos7
from rocky to stein, since we clear containers running in Docker during
the upgrade, so they run on Podman.

In reality, the future platform won't have Docker installed, so this
role will become useless and we'll probably deprecate it.

Closes-Bug: #1824301
Change-Id: Ic5036ffa756775e3806e18b09e034af2290bfb56

commit_message:
Remove in-tree periodic job

The periodic job is defined in both openstack/project-config and here.
Remove it here and keep the version in project-config so that we can
update it easily for all projects for train.

Related changes:
* https://review.opendev.org/654571
* https://review.opendev.org/654574

Change-Id: I4408048391dc9a286d8d6ab8f8424a659b1b00ed
(cherry picked from commit 286e54d10a0bec1c01fe97cc1079e3dd1c1d9c22)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/78/654578/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Update image links for Ceph.

Updated the links according to the decision here [1].
The convention for images is <imagename>:<tagging>
where <tagging> takes the format <version>-<distro>.

[1]: http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-helm/%23openstack-helm.2019-03-07.log.html#t2019-03-07T17:50:58

Change-Id: I84f8ce731e428f8ef035c008ff615e712c78a1f4

commit_message:
Add Managers<->Systems linkage in sushy-emulator

Redfish BMC is based on three key components: Systems, Managers
and Chassis. While each component has its own properties and
behaviours, however in some situations these components may need
to one another.

This change adds one-to-many style linkage between each of
these three objects.

Change-Id: Ia6cba82125c193f90cea9c67b6110cc4ebf264de

This change adds apparently missing Systems->Manager linkage
in the Redfish JSON document rendered by the REST API

commit_message:
Fix Swift Rate Calculation

* To find the oldest and newest quantities
  for calculating rate, Spark Data Frame
  is converted to a Spark RDD, which makes it
  easy to do a group by and sort. The syntax to pull
  the value from a map column type in an
  RDD is rdd.map_column['key'] which
  is different from dataframe.map_column.key
  which was causing  'dict' object has no attribute
  exception

* Renamed first_attempt_at_spark_test.py to
  test_first_attempt_at_spark, because all the tests
  in that file were not being run.

* Changed the pre transform and transform specs
  which were being used by test_first_attempt_at_spark
  to newer 'dimensions#field_name that was introduced
  in rocky release.

Story: 2005449
Task: 30501

Change-Id: I6adeee54fe261c535372b8f5f3580e7d3261259b

commit_message:
Remove in-tree periodic job

The periodic job is defined in both openstack/project-config and here.
Remove it here and keep the version in project-config so that we can
update it easily for all projects for train.

Related changes:
* https://review.opendev.org/654571
* https://review.opendev.org/654574

Change-Id: I4408048391dc9a286d8d6ab8f8424a659b1b00ed
(cherry picked from commit 286e54d10a0bec1c01fe97cc1079e3dd1c1d9c22)

commit_message:
Touch the README

The command "git name-rev 05ca984219b8fb6d6fed708061d81d82e8c77a0f"
is segfaulting on this repo, which is causing Gitea to be unable
to serve it.  Gitea is likely running that command because that is
the most recent commit to the README.  Bury it by creating a newer
one which will, one hopes, not cause a segfault in name-rev.

Change-Id: I80ebe63137131e2e0d58947651784f3b682f2ac8

subject: libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-17 19:05:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/acc3e4d5409ca42ab1c998784ae77e2afe8eecc6', 'message': 'libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

 Conflicts:
	nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/volume/test_volume.py

NOTE(melwitt): Conflict is due to not having change
Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355 in Pike.

commit_message:
libvirt: set device address tag only if setting disk unit

In Pike, we began setting disk unit values manually for the
'virtio-scsi' controller model in order to allow up to 256 devices [1].
We do this by setting the disk unit of the address tag manually for the
guest config. If we do not set the address tag manually, libvirt would
autogenerate it for us.

A problem occurs when a user has a SCSI disk that is a volume or isn't
using the 'virtio-scsi' controller model because we're not guarding our
manual setting of the address tag in the guest config by the disk unit,
in addition to the SCSI bus. This means that for a SCSI volume, we
generate an address tag like '<address type="drive" controller="0"/>'
for any SCSI volume, so a user with more than one device will get the
following error when they try to boot an instance:

  Failed to start libvirt guest: libvirtError: unsupported
    configuration: Found duplicate drive address for disk with target name
    'sda' controller='0' bus='0' target='0' unit='0'

This updates the conditionals to only manually set the address tag if
the bus is SCSI _and_ the disk unit has been specified. Otherwise, let
libvirt autogenerate the address tag and take care of avoiding
collisions.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1686116

Closes-Bug: #1792077

 Conflicts:
     nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/volume/test_volume.py

NOTE(melwitt): Conflict is due to not having change
Ibfa64f18bbd2fb70db7791330ed1a64fe61c1355 in Pike.

Change-Id: Iefab05e84ccc0bf8f15bdbbf515a290d282dbc5d
(cherry picked from commit 48fd81648a7cadf2d147a6beabac067c28b288b0)
(cherry picked from commit 7500c1910cf1cbe16ee48028b67aa919160f44da)
(cherry picked from commit 8703282508954596e1d041340878c636693d8f5f)
(cherry picked from commit c8ad9f4e1949ce6fdada565cc6660fbac7f75d6c)

added_lines: # NOTE(melwitt): We set the device address unit number manually in the # case of the virtio-scsi controller, in order to allow attachment of # up to 256 devices. So, we should only be setting the address tag # if we intend to set the unit number. Otherwise, we will let libvirt # handle autogeneration of the address tag. # See https://bugs.launchpad.net/nova/+bug/1792077 for details. if disk_unit is not None: # The driver is responsible to create the SCSI controller # at index 0. info.device_addr = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestDeviceAddressDrive() info.device_addr.controller = 0
deleted_lines: # The driver is responsible to create the SCSI controller # at index 0. info.device_addr = vconfig.LibvirtConfigGuestDeviceAddressDrive() info.device_addr.controller = 0 if disk_unit is not None:

Remove openstack-tox-py35-with-neutron-lib-master

remove it again.

Rabbitmq: Fix security context

This PS fixes the use of the security context macros for the
rabbitmq chart

[DNM] Test bulk port mac fix

This is a null commit that exists purely to exercise tests, so that we
can see if the fix for bulk port mac addresses works.

deleted_lines: """ XStatic resource package See package 'XStatic' for documentation and basic tools. """ # official name, upper/lowercase allowed, no spaces DISPLAY_NAME = 'angular-ui-router' # name used for PyPi PACKAGE_NAME = 'XStatic-%s' % DISPLAY_NAME NAME = __name__.split('.')[-1] # package name (e.g. 'foo' or 'foo_bar') # please use a all-lowercase valid python # package name VERSION = '0.3.1' # version of the packaged files, please use the upstream # version number BUILD = '4' # our package build number, so we can release new builds # with fixes for xstatic stuff. PACKAGE_VERSION = VERSION + '.' + BUILD # version used for PyPi DESCRIPTION = "%s %s (XStatic packaging standard)" % (DISPLAY_NAME, VERSION) PLATFORMS = 'any' CLASSIFIERS = [] KEYWORDS = 'angular ui-router xstatic' # XStatic-* package maintainer: MAINTAINER = 'Richard Jones' MAINTAINER_EMAIL = 'r1chardj0n3s@gmail.com' # this refers to the project homepage of the stuff we packaged: HOMEPAGE = 'https://github.com/angular-ui/ui-router' # this refers to all files: LICENSE = '(same as %s)' % DISPLAY_NAME from os.path import join, dirname BASE_DIR = join(dirname(__file__), 'data') # linux package maintainers just can point to their file locations like this: #BASE_DIR = '/usr/share/javascript/' + NAME # location of the Javascript file that's the entry point for this package, if # one exists, relative to BASE_DIR MAIN=u'angular-ui-router.js' LOCATIONS = { # CDN locations (if no public CDN exists, use an empty dict) # if value is a string, it is a base location, just append relative # path/filename. if value is a dict, do another lookup using the # relative path/filename you want. # your relative path/filenames should usually be without version # information, because either the base dir/url is exactly for this # version or the mapping will care for accessing this version. }

commit_message:
Add list of packages to install lookup

This new lookup makes easy to check into any folder list
(for example /etc/ansible/roles), find in these folder the
variable files for a distribution (given in lookup parameters),
find the system packages to install for this distribution.

In short with one lookup, you get exactly the list of what you
will be installing on your host.

You can blacklist variable names (standard matching) and
package names (regexp matching).

This lookup could technically be replaced by jinja on the
py_pkgs output, but:
- We would then need to build the pkg_blacklist into the
  jinja everytime
- We would need to build the "convenience mapping" into
  the jinja everytime
This makes it simple and re-usable.

Change-Id: I74d498fbe9e61df854aa766b6e3dc84d82f2c6c0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-plugins refs/changes/74/449274/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2017, Rackspace US, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. # # (c) 2017, Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe.evrard@rackspace.co.uk> # Take a list of paths for a distro, returns which system packages # (distro_packages, apt_packages, yum_packages) will be installed. # Outputs a list. # example: # tasks: # - debug: # var: item # with_packages_to_install: # - from: # - /etc/ansible/roles # - ./ # for: trusty # #pkg_blacklist: [] # #var_blacklist: [] import os import re import yaml # import ansible things from ansible.plugins.lookup import LookupBase from ansible.errors import AnsibleLookupError try: from __main__ import display except ImportError: from ansible.utils.display import Display display = Display() BUILT_IN_DISTRO_PACKAGE_VARS = [ 'distro_packages', 'apt_packages', 'yum_packages' ] # Convenience mappings distro_specific_paths = {} distro_specific_paths['trusty'] = ['/vars/ubuntu-14.04.', '/vars/ubuntu.', '/vars/debian.', '/vars/main.'] distro_specific_paths['xenial'] = ['/vars/ubuntu-16.04.', '/vars/ubuntu.', '/vars/debian.', '/vars/main.'] distro_specific_paths['ubuntu-14.04'] = ['/vars/ubuntu-14.04.', '/vars/ubuntu.', '/vars/debian', '/vars/main'] distro_specific_paths['ubuntu-16.04'] = ['/vars/ubuntu-16.04.', '/vars/ubuntu.', '/vars/debian', '/vars/main'] distro_specific_paths['redhat-7'] = ['/vars/redhat-7.', '/vars/redhat.', '/vars/main.'] generic_paths = ['/defaults/', '/user_'] def filter_files(file_names, file_name_words): """Filter the files and return a sorted list. :type file_names: :type ext: ``str`` or ``tuple`` :returns: ``list`` """ extensions = ('yaml','yml') _file_names = list() # Uncomment out this for debugging purposes #print("Filtering according to words {}".format(file_name_words)) for file_name in file_names: if file_name.endswith(extensions): if any(i in file_name for i in file_name_words): # Uncomment out this for listing the matching files #print("Filename {} is a match".format(file_name)) _file_names.append(file_name) else: return _file_names def get_files(path): paths = os.walk(os.path.abspath(path)) files = list() for fpath, _, afiles in paths: for afile in afiles: files.append(os.path.join(fpath, afile)) else: return files def get_package_list(distro, path, var_blacklist, pkg_blacklist): path_triggers = [] path_triggers.extend(distro_specific_paths[distro]) path_triggers.extend(generic_paths) pkg_blklst_re = "(" + ")|(".join(pkg_blacklist) + ")" packages_list = [] # Uncomment out this for debugging purposes #print("Scanning path {} for files matching distro {}".format(path,distro)) for folder in path: all_files = get_files(folder) for filename in filter_files(all_files, path_triggers): with open(filename, 'r') as f: try: loaded_config = yaml.safe_load(f.read()) except Exception as e: # Ignore loading errors, the file may be empty continue try: for key, values in loaded_config.items(): key = key.lower() for type_of_package in BUILT_IN_DISTRO_PACKAGE_VARS: if (key.endswith(type_of_package) and key not in var_blacklist): for value in values: # value is a package name if not re.match(pkg_blklst_re,value): #If package is formatted like packagename==version if value.find('=') != -1: packages_list.append(value.split('=')[0]) else: packages_list.append(value) except AttributeError as e: continue return packages_list class LookupModule(LookupBase): def run(self, terms, variables=None, **kwargs): term_pkgs = [] for term in terms: if isinstance(term, dict): paths = term.get('from', []) distro = term.get('for', "") pkg_blacklist = term.get('pkg_blacklist', []) var_blacklist = term.get('var_blacklist', []) else: raise AnsibleLookupError("Lookup item should be a dict") if not distro: raise AnsibleLookupError("Distro (for:) cannot be empty") if not paths: raise AnsibleLookupError("Locations (from:) cannot be empty") term_pkgs.extend(get_package_list(distro, paths, var_blacklist, pkg_blacklist)) return term_pkgs # For debug purposes if __name__ == '__main__': import sys import json call_term = {} call_term['for'] = sys.argv[1] call_term['from'] = sys.argv[2:] call_terms = [call_term] print(json.dumps(LookupModule().run(terms=call_terms), indent=4, sort_keys=True))

commit_message:
Add documentation for consuming os_tempest role

* it adds docs for running os_tempest using playbook on
  manually deployed TripleO standalone deployment.

https://tree.taiga.io/project/tripleo-ci-board/task/872

Change-Id: I505b481acd4f2c04b02953affb607070aecfb09b
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar <chkumar@redhat.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-docs refs/changes/06/654406/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: os_tempest is the unified ansible role for installing, configuring and running tempest tests as well as processing tempest results using stackviz. Installation ------------ Follow the `os_tempest Installation guide <https://docs.openstack.org/openstack-ansible-os_tempest/latest/user/installation.html>` Once Installation is done, we can verify it using `ansible-galaxy` command. It will list os_tempest, config_template and python_venv_build role. ``` $ ansible-galaxy list ``` How to run os_tempest role using sample playbook ------------------------------------------------ In order to run os_tempest role on target host, make sure we have `clouds.yaml` is present there and it is working fine. In case of tripleo standalone deployment. we have `OS_CLOUD=standalone`. Run the following commands to verify it: ``` $ export OS_CLOUD=standalone $ openstack endpoint list ``` Now, we can create a `tempest.yaml` playbook with following vars: .. code-block:: yaml --- - hosts: localhost name: Run Tempest on Standalone vars: ansible_become: true tempest_run: 'yes' tempest_install_method: 'distro' tempest_cloud_name: 'standalone' tempest_workspace: "/home/centos/tempest" tempest_services: - neutron tempest_public_net_physical_type: 'datacentre' tempest_private_net_provider_type: 'geneve' tempest_service_setup_host: '{{ inventory_hostname }}' tempest_public_subnet_cidr: '192.168.0.0/24' tempest_public_subnet_gateway_ip: '{{ tempest_public_subnet_cidr|nthhost(1) }}' tempest_public_subnet_allocation_pools: '{{ tempest_public_subnet_cidr|nthhost(100) ~ "-" ~ tempest_public_subnet_cidr|nthhost(120) }}' tempest_use_tempestconf: true tempest_run_stackviz: false tempest_tempest_conf_overrides: auth.tempest_roles: "Member" tempest_test_whitelist: - 'tempest.api.identity.v3' gather_facts: true roles: - os_tempest What are these above vars: ++++++++++++++++++++++++++ * `ansible_become: true`: os_tempest requires root permission for installation and creation of tempest related directories * `tempest_run: 'yes'`: For running os_tempest role, by default, It is set to `no`. * `tempest_install_method: 'distro'`: Set to `distro` for installing tempest and it's plugins from distro packages * `tempest_workspace`: It is the full directory path where we want to create tempest workspace. * `tempest_cloud_name: 'standalone'`: Name of the cloud name from clouds.yaml file for using to create tempest related resources on target host. * `tempest_services`: For installing tempest plugins as well as creating pre tempest resources like networks for tempest tests. * `tempest_public_net_physical_type`: The name of public physical network. For standalone tripleo deployment, it can found under `/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/neutron/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini` and then look for the value of `flat_networks`. * `tempest_private_net_provider_type`: The Name of the private network provider type, in case of ovn deployment, it should be `geneve`. It can be found under `/var/lib/config-data/puppet-generated/neutron/etc/neutron/plugins/ml2/ml2_conf.ini` and then look for `type_drivers`. * `tempest_service_setup_host`: It should be set to ansible inventory hostname. For some operation, the ansible role delegates to inventory hostname. * `tempest_public_subnet_cidr`: Based on the standalone deployment IP, we need to pass a required cidr. * `tempest_public_subnet_gateway_ip and tempest_public_subnet_allocation_pools`: Subnet Gateway IP and allocation pool can be calculated based on the value of `tempest_public_subnet_cidr` nthhost value. * `tempest_use_tempestconf`: For generating tempest.conf, we use python-tempestconf tool. By default It is setted to false. Set to `true` for using it * `tempest_run_stackviz`: Stackviz is very useful in CI for analizing tempest results, for local use, we set it to false. By default it is setted to true. * `tempest_tempest_conf_overrides`: In order to pass additional tempest configuration to python-tempestconf tool, we can pass a dictionary of values. * `tempest_test_whitelist`: We need to pass a list of tests which we wish to run on the targest host as a list. * `tempest_test_blacklist`: In order to skip tempest tests, we can pass the list here. * `gather_facts`: We need to set gather_facts to true as os_tempest rely on targetted environment facts for installing stuff. Since we are going to run `os_tempest` role on the same standalone deployment host, so we are pointing hosts to `localhost`. How to run it? ++++++++++++++ We can `ansible-playbook` command to run the above playbook. ``` $ ansible-playbook tempest.yaml ``` Once the playbook run finishes, we can find the tempest related directories in tempest workspace. With in `tempest_workspace/etc/` dir, we can find following files: * tempest.conf * tempest_whitelist.txt * tempest_blacklist.txt With in `/var/log/tempest` dir, we can find the tempest tests results in html format. * stestr_results.html * test_list.txt
deleted_lines: At this moment we run `os_tempest` in `tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest` job where it is used for cloud validation.

commit_message:
Fix Flask config load under WSGI

Fixes Flask config file load as pointed by the `SUSHY_EMULATOR_CONFIG`
environment variable when running under WSGI server. Before this fix,
the above mentioned environment variable was ignored and user config
file not loaded.

Change-Id: I79890bb2db0a40effdb8fa78dab6c0b3ceb9d0f8
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sushy-tools refs/changes/07/648407/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes Flask config file load as pointed by the ``SUSHY_EMULATOR_CONFIG`` environment variable when running under WSGI server. Before this fix, the above mentioned environment variable was ignored and user config file not loaded.

Change-Id: I6e3ae377c37fb8b72b5ff913154f7763d1691b25

commit_message:
Make utility install playbook idempotent

To ensure idempotence we do the following:

1. Ensure that the symlinks are only changed if
   they do not yet exist.
2. Switch the openstack client bash completion to
   be a handler which is executed whenever the
   venv changes or the symlinks change.

Change-Id: I6e3ae377c37fb8b72b5ff913154f7763d1691b25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/95/653395/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: handlers: - name: Create openstack client bash_completion script shell: >- openstack complete > /etc/bash_completion.d/openstack_client args: executable: /bin/bash listen: - "venv changed" set -e return_code=0 if [[ -e "{{ utility_venv_bin }}/{{ _bin_name }}" && ! -L "/usr/local/bin/{{ _bin_name }}" ]]; then return_code=2 exit ${return_code} register: _client_symlink changed_when: _client_symlink.rc == 2 failed_when: _client_symlink.rc not in [0,2] notify: "Create openstack client bash_completion script"
deleted_lines: if [[ -e "{{ utility_venv_bin }}/{{ _bin_name }}" ]]; then - name: Create openstack client bash_completion script shell: | openstack complete > /etc/bash_completion.d/openstack_client

commit_message:
Add cassandra support

Support Cassandra db installation and Cassandra related
configurations for Monasca api and persister services
in devstack. Add Monasca rest API Cassandra plugin for
retrieving metric, dimension, measurement, statistics
and alarms.

Also includes the equivalent of
commit eb78188f97c8576fc39c1dbb7057bddf4fc56113 as the
previous commit 011db48a92a2b... was not compatible.

Depends-On: I4bbe48f8fe550385de6ed3e14120850a8542c7c9
Change-Id: Ie60d668692e1f25f555dda2355f4e513d582736c
story: 2001231
task: 5759

added_lines: // (C) Copyright 2017 SUSE LLC // // Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); // you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. // You may obtain a copy of the License at // // http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 // // Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software // distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, // WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or // implied. // See the License for the specific language governing permissions and // limitations under the License. // version 1.0 drop schema if exists monasca; // replication factor is set to 1 for devstack installation create schema monasca with replication = { 'class' : 'SimpleStrategy', 'replication_factor' : 1 }; create table monasca.measurements ( metric_id blob, region text static, tenant_id text static, metric_name text static, dimensions frozen<list<text>> static, time_stamp timestamp, value double, value_meta text, primary key (metric_id, time_stamp) ) WITH CLUSTERING ORDER BY (time_stamp ASC); create table monasca.metrics ( region text, tenant_id text, metric_name text, dimensions frozen<list<text>>, dimension_names frozen<list<text>>, metric_id blob, created_at timestamp, updated_at timestamp, primary key ((region, tenant_id, metric_name), dimensions, dimension_names) ); CREATE CUSTOM INDEX metrics_created_at_index ON monasca.metrics (created_at) USING 'org.apache.cassandra.index.sasi.SASIIndex'; CREATE CUSTOM INDEX metrics_updated_at_index ON monasca.metrics (updated_at) USING 'org.apache.cassandra.index.sasi.SASIIndex'; create table monasca.dimensions ( region text, tenant_id text, name text, value text, primary key ((region, tenant_id, name), value) ); create table monasca.dimensions_metrics ( region text, tenant_id text, dimension_name text, dimension_value text, metric_name text, primary key ((region, tenant_id, dimension_name, dimension_value), metric_name) ); create table monasca.metrics_dimensions ( region text, tenant_id text, dimension_name text, dimension_value text, metric_name text, primary key ((region, tenant_id, metric_name), dimension_name, dimension_value) ); create table monasca.alarm_state_history ( tenant_id text, alarm_id text, time_stamp timestamp, metric text, old_state text, new_state text, reason text, reason_data text, sub_alarms text, primary key ((tenant_id, alarm_id), time_stamp) );

subject: Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-24 15:10:05.000000000', 'files': ['unit_tests/test_lxd_utils.py', 'hooks/lxd_utils.py', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-lxd/commit/6c61ad42b56866aa1dd5d031fda31b88d92d7c7b', 'message': 'Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Closes-Bug: #1825393
(cherry picked from commit 4bf72620c3cf9cef5905a07132510df2cec5de41)

Change-Id: Ieb8b5c3cfd13b2a601d79fa7a99d29229acc287e
'}]
commit_message:
Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Closes-Bug: #1825393
(cherry picked from commit 4bf72620c3cf9cef5905a07132510df2cec5de41)

Change-Id: Ieb8b5c3cfd13b2a601d79fa7a99d29229acc287e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-nova-lxd refs/changes/70/655470/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix LP access credentials

In the Great Migration of 2019, the consumer_key name used in the
credentials used by release jobs to update Launchpad bugs was
updated, breaking our connections to LP.

Since switching to a fully new key is non-trivial, let's restore
the old, working, albeit slightly wrong key name.

Change-Id: I71c37d1f77db63d181cb054ba37536f4f3c51aac

commit_message:
Fix detection of already initialised lxc storage pool

The related bug was caused because the charm did not detect when
the lxc storage had already been set up using the `lxc storage`
command which is used in the 3.x series, rather than the old way
with the 2.x series.

Also fixes issue on xenial where linux-image-extra-* has been renamed to
linux-modules-extra-* from from -4.4.0-145-generic onwards.  Otherwise,
the install fails on xenial.

Change-Id: If8bdad6f5641ee21fc7860dceeb4c3facbaecc76
Closes-Bug: #1825393

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-03-01 19:51:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.cache/commit/90e34ff8a9283780e9953c497c4a650858af136b', 'message': "Fix memcache pool client in monkey-patched environments

First off, this is an ugly hack, but we're dealing with code that
essentially monkey-patches a monkey-patch. You reap what you sow.

Per the linked bug, our connection pool client explodes on python 3
with eventlet monkey-patching in force:

TypeError: object() takes no parameters

This is due to the way __new__ is overridden in the class. We need
to strip arguments from the call before they get to object(), which
doesn't accept args.

Unfortunately, when we're _not_ monkey-patched, adding the new
override implementation fails with:

TypeError: object.__new__(_MemcacheClient) is not safe,
use Client.__new__()

As such, we need different implementations depending on whether we
are monkey-patched or not. This change passes both with and without
monkey-patching and adds a unit test that exposes the bug.

Note that this is a temporary, backportable fix that will ultimately
be replaced by a switch to the pymemcache library which does not
have the threading.local problem being worked around here.

Change-Id: I039dffadeebd0ff4479b9c870c257772c43aba53

commit_message:
Fix memcache pool client in monkey-patched environments

First off, this is an ugly hack, but we're dealing with code that
essentially monkey-patches a monkey-patch. You reap what you sow.

Per the linked bug, our connection pool client explodes on python 3
with eventlet monkey-patching in force:

TypeError: object() takes no parameters

This is due to the way __new__ is overridden in the class. We need
to strip arguments from the call before they get to object(), which
doesn't accept args.

Unfortunately, when we're _not_ monkey-patched, adding the new
override implementation fails with:

TypeError: object.__new__(_MemcacheClient) is not safe,
use Client.__new__()

As such, we need different implementations depending on whether we
are monkey-patched or not. This change passes both with and without
monkey-patching and adds a unit test that exposes the bug.

Note that this is a temporary, backportable fix that will ultimately
be replaced by a switch to the pymemcache library which does not
have the threading.local problem being worked around here.

Change-Id: I039dffadeebd0ff4479b9c870c257772c43aba53
Partial-Bug: 1812935
Closes-Bug: 1812672
(cherry picked from commit f4a25f642991a7114b86f6eb7d0bac3d599953a6)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.cache refs/changes/00/640500/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_can_create_with_kwargs(self): """Test for lp 1812935 Note that in order to reproduce the bug, it is necessary to add the following to the top of oslo_cache/tests/__init__.py:: import eventlet eventlet.monkey_patch() This should happen before any other imports in that file. """ client = _memcache_pool._MemcacheClient('foo', check_keys=False) # Make sure kwargs are properly processed by the client self.assertFalse(client.do_check_key) # Make sure our __new__ override still results in the right type self.assertIsInstance(client, _memcache_pool._MemcacheClient)

commit_message:
Add exact match aggregate image properties matcher/filter

This filter is a variant of the AggregateImagePropertiesIsolation
but is distinct enough that it should likely be its own thing.

The reasoning behind it is that the existing filter is a little
to tolerant of missing image properties (when you really want it
to match exactly) and to setup your aggregates and images with that
filter is very tedious, fragile, and error prone.

So instead of that filter, this filter uses some of the same concepts
but is less tolerant of missing image properties (for example when
you setup a windows only hypervisor set you do not want other images
with various other properties to end up there).

Co-author: Elancheran Subramanian <esubramanian@godaddy.com>

Change-Id: I9ba17489b914edeb7e882380d98ac497ddc0b383
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/70/599870/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: """), cfg.StrOpt("aggregate_image_property_key", default="os_type", deprecated_group="DEFAULT", help=""" Image property key which can be used for the exact property match filter Images and hosts can be configured so that certain images can only be scheduled to hosts in a particular aggregate. This is done with metadata values set on the host aggregate that are identified by beginning with the value of this option. If the host is part of an aggregate with such a metadata key, the image in the request spec must have the value of that metadata in its properties in order for the scheduler to consider the host as acceptable. Key should be one of the property of Image Object.

commit_message:
Add apply_cells to nova-manage

This adds a new apply_cells method to the nova-manage commands that
reads in a specification file (json or yaml) and sets up the
configurations based on the specifications within the file. This
feature matches cell_mappings to specifications based on its name and
will "make-it-so" for cell_mappings by:
* create_cell (spec exists with a name not already in cell_mappings),
* update_cell (spec and mapping exist, but have different values),
* delete_cell (spec file does not have a matching cell by name).

There is a --dry-run argument that can be used to see what would change
without actually performing any modifications.

This should allow automated systems that want to source control (git or
inventory generated) how their cells are setup and managed.

Change-Id: I7a60a02637d85f576d4be6d9ea8a5e2a01360d0c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/50/599050/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yamlfrom oslo_utils import strutils @action_description( _("Takes a file with a list of cell specifications and applies it to " "the system. This matches cells by name, creates cells that do " "not exist, updates matched cells where information has changed, " "and deletes cells that are not within this list. The result " "returns the max return code from all of the functions it " "performed.")) @args('--cell-specs-file', metavar='<path_to_specs_file>', help=_("A json or yaml list of cell specifications that contain: " "name (used as the unique key to the cell), " "database_connection, transport_url, disabled. Sample " "file: "''' [ { "name": "cell0", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url0>", "transport_url": null, "disabled": false }, { "name": "cell1", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url1>", "transport_url": "<transport_url1>", "disabled": false }, { "name": "cell2", "database_connection": "<database_connection_url2>", "transport_url": "<transport_url2>", "disabled": true } ]''')) @args('--dry-run', action='store_true', help=_('When set, simply outputs what changes would have been ' 'performed without actually applying the changes.')) @args('--verbose', action='store_true', help=_('More verbose output depending on sub-functions called.')) @args('--force', action='store_true', help=_('Force changes where applicable. This is forwarded on to ' 'this class sub-functions that use it (Default False)')) def apply_cells(self, cell_specs_file=None, verbose=False, dry_run=False, force=False): """Reads a cell spec file and applies specs until cell mappings match. :param cell_specs_file: The file to read the cell specifications from. :param verbose: More verbose output depending on sub-functions called. :param dry_run: Run this in "test" mode showing changes but not applying them. :param force: Apply force for functions requesting it (delete_cell) :return: The maximum return result of all of the sub-functions that were called while synchronizing cells to match the specifications. """ if not cell_specs_file: print(_('Must specify --cell-specs-file as a path to a ' 'file with a json or yaml list of cells.')) return 1 if not os.path.exists(cell_specs_file): print(_('The path specified by --cell-specs-file does not exist.')) return 1 # Retrieve all the specs, validate and index by name required_fields = ['name', 'database_connection', 'transport_url'] specs = self._parse_json_or_yaml(cell_specs_file) specs_by_name = {} err = 0 for spec in specs: for field in required_fields: if field not in spec: err = 1 print('The required field %s is missing from a row in ' '--cell-specs-file' % field) specs_by_name[spec['name']] = spec if err: return 1 # Retrieve existing cells, validate, and index by name cell_mappings = objects.CellMappingList.get_all( context.get_admin_context()) cells_by_name = {} for cell_mapping in cell_mappings: name = getattr(cell_mapping, 'name') if name is None: # TODO(wwriverrat) Can we find a match without raising error? # This will be a common occurrence for those who have used # simple cell setup and the initial cell's name is not set print(_("Error - Existing cell_mapping missing name found. " "Have discovered an existing cell without a name." "This apply_cells function attempts to map your " "specification by name and does not know how to " "handle existing cells without names. Please consider " "calling the cell_v2 update command against any " "existing unnamed cells (ideally matching your spec " "if the cell already exists.")) return 1 else: cells_by_name[cell_mapping.name] = cell_mapping # Use python set functions to determine high-level differences adds = set(specs_by_name).difference(cells_by_name.keys()) similars = set(specs_by_name).intersection(cells_by_name.keys()) deletes = set(cells_by_name).difference(specs_by_name.keys()) result = 0 total_changes = 0 # TODO(wwriverrat) Consider starting txn here and commit when done? # New cells. Add them. for name in adds: cell_spec = specs_by_name[name] if dry_run: print(_("Would have created cell %(name)s with details: " "%(msk)r") % {'name': name, 'msk': self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec)}) else: add_result = self.create_cell( name=cell_spec['name'], database_connection=cell_spec['database_connection'], transport_url=cell_spec['transport_url'], verbose=verbose, disabled=strutils.bool_from_string(cell_spec['disabled'])) print(_("Create cell %(res)s creating cell %(name)s: %(msk)r") % {'res': 'failed' if add_result else 'succeeded', 'name': name, 'msk': self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec)}) result = max(result, add_result) total_changes += 1 # Cell exists but needs to compare all fields to see if updates needed for name in similars: cell_mapping = cells_by_name[name] cell_spec = specs_by_name[name] changed = False diff_fields = required_fields + ['disabled'] for field in diff_fields: field_changed = getattr(cell_mapping, field) != cell_spec.get(field, None) if field_changed: if field in ['database_connection', 'transport_url']: val_cell = mask_passwd_in_url(getattr(cell_mapping, field)) val_spec = mask_passwd_in_url(cell_spec.get(field)) else: val_cell = getattr(cell_mapping, field) val_spec = cell_spec.get(field) print(_('For cell %(name)s, field %(fld)s does not match: ' 'cell value (%(valc)s) is not same as spec value ' '(%(vals)s)') % {'name': cell_mapping.name, 'fld': field, 'valc': val_cell, 'vals': val_spec}) changed = changed or field_changed if changed: if dry_run: print(_("Would have updated cell %(name)s from %(pre)r " "to %(post)r") % {'name': name, 'pre': self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping), 'post': self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec)}) else: # Need to update existing record disabled = strutils.bool_from_string( cell_spec.get('disabled', 'false')) update_result = self.update_cell( cell_mapping.uuid, name=cell_mapping.name, transport_url=cell_spec['transport_url'], db_connection=cell_spec['database_connection'], disable=disabled, enable=not disabled) print(_("Update cell %(res)s modifying cell %(name)s: " "%(msk)r") % {'res': 'failed' if update_result else 'succeeded', 'name': name, 'msk': self._masked_cell_spec(cell_spec)} ) result = max(result, update_result) total_changes += 1 else: print(_("Cell and spec for %s matches. Nothing to do.") % name) # Cells not in the spec get deleted for name in deletes: cell_mapping = cells_by_name[name] if dry_run: print(_("Would have deleted cell %(name)s with details: " "%(msk)r") % {'name': name, 'msk': self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping)}) else: delete_result = self.delete_cell(cell_mapping.uuid, force=force) if delete_result == 0: print(_("Successfully deleted cell %(name)s: %(msk)r") % {'name': name, 'msk': self._masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping)}) else: print(_("Attempt to delete cell %(name)s (uuid %(uuid)s) " "returned unsuccessful response %(delres)i. " "You may wish to review and remove all mappings " "within that cell and try again.") % {'name': name, 'uuid': cell_mapping.uuid, 'delres': delete_result}) result = max(result, delete_result) total_changes += 1 if total_changes: print(_("There were %(tot)i changes applied to your cells. You " "should consider restarting services that depend on this " "cell data being up to date (i.e. nova-scheduler, etc).") % {'tot': total_changes}) else: print(_("No changes applied. Your cells are all in sync. Yippee!")) return result @staticmethod def _masked_cell_mapping(cell_mapping): return { 'uuid': cell_mapping.uuid, 'name': cell_mapping.name, 'database_connection': mask_passwd_in_url( cell_mapping.database_connection), 'transport_url': mask_passwd_in_url(cell_mapping.transport_url), 'disabled': cell_mapping.disabled, } @staticmethod def _masked_cell_spec(cell_info): db = cell_info.get('database_connection', None) xport = cell_info.get('transport_url', None) return { 'name': cell_info.get('name', None), 'database_connection': None if not db else mask_passwd_in_url(db), 'transport_url': None if not xport else mask_passwd_in_url(xport), 'disabled': cell_info.get('disabled') } @staticmethod def _parse_json_or_yaml(file_location): """Parse the raw contents of a data file. Parses the contents of a file which can be in either yaml or json format. Both can be parsed as yaml. :param file_location: A string containing a path to a file of json or yaml format. :returns: The file contents converted to python objects. """ try: with open(file_location) as fh: parsed = yaml.safe_load(fh) except yaml.YAMLError as e: raise ValueError(six.text_type(e)) return parsed or []

commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ia8532570e5c0356bdf289bb99c1a8c46ee395893

Add delay option to std.echo to emulate external lags.

Change-Id: Id177246996434d2ad1c111b0b7bf78664390045a
Signed-off-by: Oleg Ovcharuk <vgvoleg@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Move release version to different file

Without this patch, the version is included in a bigger variable
file, and is marginally harder to automate.

This fixes the problem by separating the version to a new file,
as it was decided during the PTG.

Change-Id: I78bd1ff56440da6d8a8fda91ab2e9fb9d106d208

commit_message:
[WIP] Ensure python3-pkg-resources is installed

Makes the requirement to install python3-pkg-resources explicit,
to fix circular dependencies.

Note:
I am not sure we should do this, but instead clean the python3
from ubuntu 16.04, and start fresh with ubuntu 18.04, as 18.04 is
now out. Or if we wholly switch to python3 later. But consistency
is good, and being dual stack doesn't seem to help.

Change-Id: I5b682dff891349334f1161de7cfa09f484701219

Ib07b7b4200b5cf3a34b8eed441e6754da7d446cf

subject: Make docs be container agnostic
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-03-12 12:57:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible/commit/5c4eaca258e3696ef39a6f85c7f6c1114f6def83', 'message': 'Make docs be container agnostic

If the documentation has a reference of lxc container, that
documentation wouldn't apply on nspawn world. This changes
the references to use a more common "containers-create",
and "containers-destroy".

At the same time, to avoid repeating ourselves, we modify the
"containers-deploy" mechanism to call the newly created
"containers-create".

commit_message:
Make docs be container agnostic

If the documentation has a reference of lxc container, that
documentation wouldn't apply on nspawn world. This changes
the references to use a more common "containers-create",
and "containers-destroy".

At the same time, to avoid repeating ourselves, we modify the
"containers-deploy" mechanism to call the newly created
"containers-create".

Change-Id: Icd6a64968a0b2d606f08fcb94495413ca91b188e

subject: [WIP] "Higher performance" memcached driver
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2018-02-05 17:07:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_keystone/commit/7c359539799cc7966c3c10dc91a506f44d2e1d0c', 'message': '[WIP] "Higher performance" memcached driver

According to keystone sample configuration, the
oslo_cache.memcache_pool should be used for eventlet-based
or highly threaded servers [1], while
dogpile.cache.memcached should be used for low thread servers
[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good
enough for us.

My test don't show any performance difference when two
backends servers are used and one is down: Both settings
are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling?)

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

According to keystone sample configuration, the

or highly threaded servers [1], while
dogpile.cache.memcached should be used for low thread servers
[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good

My test don't show any performance difference when two
backends servers are used and one is down: Both settings
are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling).

According to kmalloc:
"the memcache pool uses a fixed number of connections
 instead of a one-per-request model. It was designed to
 help in the case of eventlet, however, it can cause more
 latency/blocking on getting data because the pool has a
 fixed size."


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

Change-Id: Ice6eabd4392c2b35f84289d1065acf76dd05a7b7
'}]
commit_message:
[WIP] "Higher performance" memcached driver

According to keystone sample configuration, the
oslo_cache.memcache_pool should be used for eventlet-based
or highly threaded servers [1], while
dogpile.cache.memcached should be used for low thread servers
[2]. Because we don't use redis, memcached should be good
enough for us.

My test don't show any performance difference when two
backends servers are used and one is down: Both settings
are slow: They both query the dead server.
Performance optimizations are probably elsewhere when
memcached servers are online (proper object
pooling).

According to kmalloc:
"the memcache pool uses a fixed number of connections
 instead of a one-per-request model. It was designed to
 help in the case of eventlet, however, it can cause more
 latency/blocking on getting data because the pool has a
 fixed size."


[1]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L501
[2]: https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/775deeae0c99bd98595890ef9840dce9c6d917d8/etc/keystone.conf.sample#L502

Change-Id: Ice6eabd4392c2b35f84289d1065acf76dd05a7b7

commit_message:
Test keystone with a memcached pool

On top of testing keystone with just one server, we should
test it with a pool of nodes, to see how it behaves.

added_lines: #!/usr/bin/env python """ This is a command line tool to manage openstack-ansible inventory. """ import click import json import logging import yaml CONTEXT_SETTINGS = dict(help_option_names=['-h', '--help']) @click.group(context_settings=CONTEXT_SETTINGS) def router(): #pragma: no cover """ Command line tool to manage openstack-ansible inventory """ logging.getLogger().setLevel(logging.INFO) @router.command() @click.option( '-f', '--file', metavar="openstack_inventory.json", help='Inventory file to load for migration', default='/etc/openstack_deploy/openstack_inventory.json', type=click.File('r')) @click.option( '-d', '--directory', help='Inventory folder for outputting the results of the migration', #default='/etc/openstack_deploy/inventory/' default='./folder/' ) def migrate(**kwargs): """ Take an existing openstack_inventory.json and generates a list of static files for ansible consumption (inventory file and hostvars)""" try: inventory = json.loads(kwargs['file'].read()) except ValueError: raise SystemExit("Invalid JSON Inventory file") else: # Generate host vars folder = './folder/' for host, host_data in inventory['_meta']['hostvars'].items(): container_name = host_data['container_name'] filepath = folder + container_name + '.yml' hostvars = {} hostvars['physical_host'] = host_data.get('physical_host',host) hostvars['ansible_host'] = host_data['ansible_ssh_host'] hostvars['container_networks'] = host_data['container_networks'] with open(filepath, 'w') as f: f.write(yaml.safe_dump(hostvars)) # Generate user_ variables from global_overrides filepath = folder + 'user_global_overrides.yml' with open(filepath, 'w') as f: f.write(yaml.safe_dump(inventory['all']['vars'])) # Generate the proper groups @router.command() def create(**kwargs): """ Take the openstack_user_config definition, call the legacy """ pass @router.command() def add(**kwargs): """ Add a host to a series of group, depending on its profile """ pass if __name__ == '__main__': #pragma: no cover router()

commit_message:
Refactor post-run

This simplifies post-run plays. Deployers wanting to gather
logs can also do it on their machine by simply using the shell
scripts in zuul.d/playbooks.

Because post-run was defined multiple times but were inheriting
from the same job (osh-infra-functional), the post-run definition
was moved to the base job.

Finally the gathering of the logs is only done once, avoiding
ssh issues.

The previous log gathering cannot be removed until all the other
jobs using the scripts are converted.

Change-Id: I5305ef03f817f84f2b8993c04146d207b0b357e6

commit_message:
Use Ceph helpers from ``charms.openstack``

The Ceph relation adapter and keyring helper code was moved to
``charms.openstack`` as part of development of the
``ceph-rbd-mirror`` charm.

Port the Gnocchi charm to re-use this code.

Depends-On: If1d645f4708e27b724f93cac0e14431137c885d7
Depends-On: I97b4c30dabfcf65ec3fb876c2a09a44172be85e7
Change-Id: If0da7f1efcfa6b61aa210edcd76e9c3392e0e8e9

added_lines: def get_registry_response(url, token=None, decode=True): try: r = urllib2.Request(url=url) if token: r.add_header('Authorization', 'Bearer {}'.format(token)) if os.environ.get('REGISTRY_INSECURE', "False") == "True": resp = urllib2.urlopen(r, context=ssl._create_unverified_context()) else: resp = urllib2.urlopen(r) if decode: resp_text = resp.read().decode('utf-8').strip() return json.loads(resp_text) else: return resp.read() except urllib2.HTTPError as err: if err.reason == 'Not Found': return None return get_registry_response(url)['token'] return get_registry_response(url, token)['fsLayers'][0]['blobSum'] return get_registry_response(url, token, decode=False) def protocol_detection(registry): protocols = ['http','https'] errors = dict() proto = None for protocol in protocols: try: url = "{}://{}".format(protocol, registry) r = urllib2.Request(url) resp = urllib2.urlopen(r) except (urllib2.URLError,urllib2.HTTPError) as err: if err.reason == 'Forbidden': proto = protocol break else: continue except: raise else: proto = protocol break return get_registry_response(url, decode=False)def extract_container(wheels): if os.environ.get('REGISTRY_PROTOCOL') in ['http','https']: protocol = os.environ.get('REGISTRY_PROTOCOL') elif os.environ.get('REGISTRY_PROTOCOL') == 'detect': protocol = protocol_detection(registry) else: raise ValueError("Unknown protocol given in argument") registry, image, tag = parse_image(wheels) kwargs = dict() if registry: kwargs.update({'registry': registry}) kwargs.update({'token': get_token(protocol, registry, image)}) data = get_blob(image, tag, protocol, **kwargs) data = extract_container(wheels)

added_lines: function prepare_base_image { # The BASE_IMAGE provided by the user may require # building and re-use LOCI. # Test if BASE_IMAGE should be built from LOCI dockerfiles. case ${BASE_IMAGE} in ubuntu) #Mark the need to build image from LOCI Dockerfiles BUILD_IMAGE="yes" #Makes sure the name of the distro is consistent with other OSH-images. IMAGE_OS="ubuntu_xenial" ;; leap15) BUILD_IMAGE="yes" IMAGE_OS="opensuse_15" PYTHON3="yes" ;; centos) BUILD_IMAGE="yes" IMAGE_OS="centos_7" ;; debian) BUILD_IMAGE="yes" IMAGE_OS="debian" ;; *) BUILD_IMAGE="no" IMAGE_OS="${IMAGE_OS:-ubuntu_xenial}" ;; esac if [[ "${BUILD_IMAGE}" == "yes" ]]; then pushd ${LOCI_SRC_DIR} docker build --network=host \ --tag ${BASE_IMAGE} \ --force-rm --pull --no-cache \ dockerfiles/${BASE_IMAGE} popd else # If not building, fetch it first. docker pull ${BASE_IMAGE} fi } function get_build_arguments { # Apply common vars local FROM="${BASE_IMAGE}" local PROJECT="$1" local PROJECT_REF="${OPENSTACK_VERSION}" local IMAGE_TAG="${OPENSTACK_VERSION#*/}" # Apply known defaults local EXTRA_VERSION="${EXTRA_VERSION:-}" local WHEELS="${WHEELS:-}" local PROFILES="${PROFILES:-fluent}" local PIP_PACKAGES="${PIP_PACKAGES:-pycrypto}" local PIP_ARGS="${PIP_ARGS:-}" local DIST_PACKAGES="${DIST_PACKAGES:-}" local PYTHON3="${PYTHON3:-}" # Apply known extra defaults case $PROJECT in "keystone") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} apache ldap" local PIP_PACKAGES="${PIP_PACKAGES} python-openstackclient" ;; "ironic") local DIST_PACKAGES="iproute2" local PROFILES="${PROFILES} ipxe ipmi qemu tftp" ;; "neutron_sriov") local DIST_PACKAGES="ethtool lshw" local FROM="docker.io/ubuntu:18.04" local PROJECT="neutron" local EXTRA_VERSION="-sriov" local IMAGE_OS="ubuntu_bionic" ;; "heat") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} apache" ;; "glance") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} ceph" local PIP_PACKAGES="${PIP_PACKAGES} python-swiftclient" ;; "cinder") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} ceph lvm qemu" local PIP_PACKAGES="${PIP_PACKAGES} python-swiftclient" ;; "neutron") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} linuxbridge openvswitch" ;; "nova") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} ceph linuxbridge openvswitch configdrive qemu apache" ;; "horizon") local PROFILES="${PROFILES} apache" ;; "congress") local PIP_PACKAGES="${PIP_PACKAGES} python-congressclient" ;; esac if [[ "$PROJECT" != "requirements" ]]; then if [[ ! -z ${WHEELS_LOCATION} ]]; then local WHEELS="${WHEELS_LOCATION}" else local WHEELS="/opt/loci/scripts/requirements-wheels.tar" fi fi buildargs=( FROM PROJECT PROJECT_REF WHEELS PROFILES PIP_PACKAGES PIP_ARGS DIST_PACKAGES PYTHON3 ) for arg in ${buildargs[@]}; do if [[ ! -z ${!arg} ]]; then build_args="${build_args} --build-arg $arg='${!arg}'" fi done default_tag="${IMAGE_TAG}-${IMAGE_OS}" if [[ ! -z ${CHANGE_ID} ]]; then changeid_tag="change_${CHANGE_ID}_${default_tag}" build_args="${build_args} --tag ${DOCKERHUB_NAMESPACE}${PROJECT}:${changeid_tag}" fi build_args="${build_args} --tag ${DOCKERHUB_NAMESPACE}${PROJECT}:${default_tag}" echo $build_args } function build_and_extract_requirement_image { eval "${docker_build_cmd} --tag requirements:newbuild" if [[ -z ${WHEELS_LOCATION} ]]; then containerid=$(docker create requirements:newbuild) rm -f ${LOCI_SRC_DIR}/scripts/requirements-wheels.tar # Copy the wheels in scripts so that it's automatically copied docker export $containerid -o ${LOCI_SRC_DIR}/scripts/requirements-wheels.tar fi } function build_project_images { projects=( ${BUILD_PROJECTS} ) # clear action from previous install (can be in dev local builds) truncate -s 0 ${LOG} # Run the rest of the projects with parallel for project in ${projects[@]}; do project_build_args=$(get_build_arguments $project) docker_build_cmd="${BUILD_CMD} ${project_build_args} ${LOCI_SRC_DIR}" if [[ "$project" == "requirements" ]]; then # Builds immediately build_and_extract_requirement_image $docker_build_command else # Enqueue for parallel building echo "${docker_build_cmd}" >> ${LOG} fi done parallel --group -a ${LOG}function main { ( cd ${SCRIPT_DIR}/../.. set -e # The openstack branch to build, if no per project branch is given. OPENSTACK_VERSION=${OPENSTACK_VERSION:-"master"} # BASE_IMAGE represents LOCI's "base" image name. # Use ubuntu|leap15|centos|debian to build base image from LOCI's Dockerfiles # Else use a public registry image BASE_IMAGE=${BASE_IMAGE:-"gcr.io/google_containers/ubuntu-slim:0.14"} # Namespace on dockerhub used for tagging the image. # Must end with "/" DOCKERHUB_NAMESPACE="${DOCKERHUB_NAMESPACE:-openstackhelm/}" # Set this to wheels location. By default builds wheels locally, and # copy them in the process of each container build # If you define it will be fetched instead. #WHEELS_LOCATION="" # Do not pull because based is pulled just before build. # Allows building a local base image and reuse without pushing to registry. BUILD_CMD="${BUILD_CMD:-docker build --network=host --force-rm --no-cache }" # Log location LOG="${LOG:-/tmp/loci-log-actions}" # Projects to build BUILD_PROJECTS="requirements ${BUILD_PROJECTS:-keystone heat barbican glance cinder neutron neutron_sriov nova horizon senlin congress magnum ironic}" get_loci fetch_loci_version prepare_base_image build_project_images ) } main

glance_profiles=${glance_profiles:-"'fluent ceph'"} glance_pip_packages=${glance_pip_packages:-"'pycrypto python-swiftclient'"} cinder_profiles=${cinder_profiles:-"'fluent lvm ceph qemu'"} cinder_pip_packages=${cinder_pip_packages:-"'pycrypto python-swiftclient'"} neutron_profiles=${neutron_profiles:-"'fluent linuxbridge openvswitch'"} neutron_pip_packages=${neutron_pip_packages:-"pycrypto"} nova_profiles=${nova_profiles:-"'fluent ceph linuxbridge openvswitch configdrive qemu apache'"} congress_pip_packages=${congress_pip_packages:-"'pycrypto python-congressclient'"} magnum_profiles=${magnum_profiles:-"fluent"} magnum_pip_packages=${magnum_pip_packages:-"pycrypto"} commit_message:
Dropping the py35 testing

All the integration testing has been moved to
Bionic now[1] and py3.5 is not tested runtime for
Train or stable/stein[2].

As per below ML thread, we are good to drop the py35
testing now:
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/005097.html

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004647.html
[2]
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/stein.html
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/runtimes/train.html

Change-Id: Ib38da77120fd0392984388350bb785eae5893c06

commit_message:
Refactor _heal_allocations_for_instance to make place for port healing

Add a bit of extra strucutre so that port healing can be easier later

Related-Bug: #1819923

subject: Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2019-04-19 13:55:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-helm-infra/commit/f8524b81aaae42bae52bb948b4baec8948648e1b', 'message': "Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job

This adds '|| true' to the curl command for gathering metrics from
prometheus exporters in the postrun job. After the move to
minikube for single node jobs, the headless services for the
kubernetes components no longer work as intended. The addition of
'|| true' allows the post run job to continue through the list
of services tied to the prometheus exporters without the task
failing outright

Change-Id: I56f0f56b799c3df9b2bd66a2c2044d71473606e3

commit_message:
Fix prometheus metrics gathering in postrun job

This adds '|| true' to the curl command for gathering metrics from
prometheus exporters in the postrun job. After the move to
minikube for single node jobs, the headless services for the
kubernetes components no longer work as intended. The addition of
'|| true' allows the post run job to continue through the list
of services tied to the prometheus exporters without the task
failing outright

Change-Id: I56f0f56b799c3df9b2bd66a2c2044d71473606e3

In create method of backup, while doing an incremental backup all

commit_message:
Filters fetching backups for incremental backup

In create method of backup, while doing an incremental backup all
existing backup entries get fetched from DB to search for the one
to use in incremental.

Now, only required one would be fetched after adding sort_keys='created_at'
and limit=1.

Change-Id: I4ca4fd0dc3c294ebead069c5bb93e869b417439e
Closes-Bug: 1696715

commit_message:
Rehome provider_network_attribute_updates_supported to API definition

Rehomed provider_network_attribute_updates_supported to
plugins.ml2.api.MechanismDriver, in order to be inherited in other
mechanism drivers.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/651175/
Related-Bug: #1823865

Change-Id: Ie622d94fe9559a6c7d4200e4da2e2c568629908e

commit_message:
Fix {min|max}_version in ironic Adapter setup

Change If625411f40be0ba642baeb02950f568f43673655 introduced
nova.utils.get_ksa_adapter, which accepts min_version and max_version
kwargs to be passed through to the ksa Adapter constructor. These are
supposed to represent minimum and maximum *major* API versions,
min_version was erroneously set to *microversions* when setting up the
Adapter for ironicclient. This commit changes it to a major version.
(Microversion negotiation is done within ironicclient itself.)

Also, this bug went latent for several releases because a) it only seems
to be triggered when region_name is given in the conf; but also b)
ironicclient has code to discover a reasonable endpoint if passed None.
So this change also adds a warning log if we try and fail to discover
the endpoint via ksa.

Change-Id: I34a3f8d4a496217eb01790e2d124111625bf5f85
Closes-Bug: #1825583

It should not be up to the driver to handle the error. The error should
reach the manager. Moreover, handling the error in the driver and
returning nothing caused the manager to consider the step done and go to

'}]
commit_message:
Ansible module: fix clean error handling

It should not be up to the driver to handle the error. The error should
reach the manager. Moreover, handling the error in the driver and
returning nothing caused the manager to consider the step done and go to
the next one instead of interrupting the cleaning workflow

Change-Id: I3825838b5507bc735d983466aa3cac0edd4dfaca
Story: #2005357
Task: #30315
(cherry picked from commit df5261bb349dd56ac88876e14779d244bdc0beb3)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/34/652634/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- fixes: - | Fixes an issue regarding the ``ansible deployment interface`` cleaning workflow. Handling the error in the driver and returning nothing caused the manager to consider the step done and go to the next one instead of interrupting the cleaning workflow.

persisting it, this patch changes the DB interface functions in the
request spec to ignore the data keyed by the '_nova_check_type' in

commit_message:
Don't persist _nova_check_type flag in database

The rebuild flag, set in RequestSpec.scheduler_hints and keyed by
'_nova_check_type' could be accidentally persisted later via
request_spec.save() operation.

To prevent us from reading the persisted data wrongly and from
persisting it, this patch changes the DB interface functions in the
request spec to ignore the data keyed by the '_nova_check_type' in
the RequestSpec.scheduler_hints for both cases, reading and writing.

Note that this could partially be reverted in the future once we have
no case to use '_nova_check_type' refactoring the rebuild path not to
rely on the scheduler hint hack.

Change-Id: If4fc45f774b0034d56e70d79f17b9a6b197815dc
Closes-Bug: #1823369

commit_message:
Add more usage documentation

The documentation was a bit too dry. Take some information
from mikal's blogposts and expose them in the user doc section.

Change-Id: I93a91c12e78c5d56913b0953c5a9cfa16e45a265
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.privsep refs/changes/97/649997/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: oslo.privsep lets you define in your code specific functions that will run in predefined privilege contexts. This lets you run functions with more (or less) privileges than the rest of the code. Privsep functions live in a specific ``privsep`` submodule (for example, ``nova.privsep`` for nova). Defining a context ================== Contexts are defined in the ``privsep/__init__.py`` file. For example, this defines a sys_admin_pctxt with ``CAP_CHOWN``, ``CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE``, ``CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH``, ``CAP_FOWNER``, ``CAP_NET_ADMIN``, and ``CAP_SYS_ADMIN`` rights (equivalent to ``sudo`` rights):: from oslo_privsep import capabilities from oslo_privsep import priv_context sys_admin_pctxt = priv_context.PrivContext( 'nova', cfg_section='nova_sys_admin', pypath=__name__ + '.sys_admin_pctxt', capabilities=[capabilities.CAP_CHOWN, capabilities.CAP_DAC_OVERRIDE, capabilities.CAP_DAC_READ_SEARCH, capabilities.CAP_FOWNER, capabilities.CAP_NET_ADMIN, capabilities.CAP_SYS_ADMIN], ) Defining a privileged function ============================== Functions are defined in files under the ``privsep/`` subdirectory, for example in a ``privsep/motd.py`` file for functions touching the MOTD file. They make use of a decorator pointing to the context we defined above:: import nova.privsep @nova.privsep.sys_admin_pctxt.entrypoint def update_motd(message): with open('/etc/motd', 'w') as f: f.write(message) Privileged functions should be as simple, specialized and narrow as possible. For example, ``update_motd(message)`` is a lot better than ``update_file(filename, content)`` which would allow any file on the system to be overwritten. Using a privileged function =========================== To use the privileged function in the regular code, you can just call it:: import nova.privsep.motd ... nova.privsep.motd('This node is currently idle') It is better to import the complete path (``import nova.privsep.motd``) rather than the motd name (``from nova.privsep import motd``) so that it is easier to spot that the function runs in a different privileged context. For more details, you can read the following blog post: Converting from rootwrap to privsep =================================== oslo.rootwrap is a precursor of oslo.privsep to allow code to run commands under sudo if they match a predefined filter. For example, you could define a filter that would allow you to run chmod as root using the following filter:: chmod: CommandFilter, chmod, root Beyond the bad performance of calling full commands in order to accomplish simple tasks, rootwrap also led to bad security: it was difficult to filter commands in a way that would not easily allow privilege escalation. Replacing rootwrap filters with privsep functions is easy. The chmod filter above can be replaced with a function that calls ``os.chmod()``. However a straight 1:1 filter:function replacement generally results in functions that are still too broad for good security. It is better to replace each chmod rootwrap *call* by a narrow privsep function that will limit it to specific files. Sometimes it is necessary to refactor the calling code: the rootwrap design discouraged the creation of new filters and therefore often resulted in the creation of overly-broad calling functions. For more details, you can read the following blog post: * `Adding oslo privsep to a new project, a worked example`_
deleted_lines: To use oslo.privsep in a project:: import oslo_privsep You can read the following blog posts in order to know a bit more:* `Adding oslo privsep to a new project, a worked example`_

commit_message:
Fix keepalived VIP monitoring script

Currently keepalived monitors VIPs by running some shell commands
that target HAProxy. The generated shell command is invalid, which
makes keepalived log errors.

Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/test' '-S' '/var/lib/haproxy/stats' '&&' 'echo' 'show'
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: Script `haproxy` now returning 2
Tue Apr 16 11:55:57 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) failed (exited with status 2)

Fix quoting and invoke /bin/sh explicitely to fix the error:

Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019:    Command = '/usr/bin/sh' '-c' 'test -S /var/lib/haproxy/stats && echo show info | socat /var/lib/haproxy/stats stdio'
Thu Apr 18 13:16:35 2019: VRRP_Script(haproxy) succeeded

Change-Id: I5a757f88963270e77c8ec411cd292a30f89c6bc0
Closes-Bug: #1825366

commit_message:
Remove Pike jobs and make Queens non-voting

Now that Stein is out and Pike has entered extended maintenance,
remove the Pike jobs and make Queens non-voting in preparation for
adding Stein jobs (will be done separately when the gate stabilizes).

Change-Id: Ie0f0b93f66d059d02c6d551e6f2f847460845a57

commit_message:
Remove reference to blueprints

Our feature delivery planning process revolves around specs and
we rarely use blueprints anymore.  Remove reference to blueprints
from the documentation.

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I3d9483cfb50f11c1c32f5a5bc4ae984e2e6bd3f6
